Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Public Space in the Contemporary City

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
By 2030, according to the World Health Organization, 6 out of 10 human beings will live in cities. A century ago, only 2 out of 10 did. To understand the wide-ranging implications and challenges of this rapid transformation of the typical human habitat, the NSF Cultural Anthropology Program funds scientific research on contemporary urban environments. The focus of this project is the changing nature of urban public space. In parks, squares, and sidewalks, city dwellers encounter each other and engage in public activities that help forge the bonds of community and citizenship. Historically, access to such spaces has been uneven across urban populations. This research project seeks to understand the changing functions of urban public space today.

Dr. Julian B. Brash of Montclair State University will carry out the research in New York City. Many American cities have seen restrictions on the use of public spaces and the conversion of public spaces into private ones. However, recently a number of new, high profile urban public spaces with more open access have been constructed. A particularly prominent example is a mile-long linear park built on an abandoned, elevated spur of the New York Central Railway. Using this new space as a case example, the researcher will investigate who uses such spaces, for what purposes, and how they relate to broader political, economic, social, and cultural changes in the urban environment. The researcher employs a mixed-methods scientific strategy. He and his team will conduct a formal survey of park users; carry out systematic behavioral observation scans; sample and analyze de-identified social media communications generated at the park; and carry out archival and other secondary source research. This project will generate knowledge about the changing functions and meanings of urban public space that will help build a new social scientific science of contemporary human environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This goal of this project was to examine the meanings and functions of public space in contemporary postindustrial cities of the United States and Western Europe. It would so so by focusing on the High Line, a newly built elevated park located on unused railway trestle on the west side of Manhattan in New York City. By examinging the ways in which various groups associated with the park define, enact and understand the park's public qualities via behavior, action, and discourse, this project sought to discover the civic, political, cultural, physical, and social characteristics of public space in cities, like New York, that have undergone governmental restructuring. This project utilized a mixed-­methods approach that includes ethnographic fieldwork, survey research, behavioral observation, analysis of secondary sources, and spatial analysis using GIS.

The twelve month period of behavioral observation and structured interviewing began on May 1, 2015 and concluded on May 1, 2016. The historical analysis was completed in September 2015 and the media analysis in 2017. During 2017-2018, secondary materials were digitized and coded. In 2018-2019, structured interview data and behavioral observation data were cleaned and analyzed using basic statistical techniques; in 2019-2020 behavioral observation data were analyzed using GIS. During this time, five undergraduate students from Montclair University were hired and trained. 

Data analysis has largely been completed and results continue to be written up. The central conclusion of this project is that the High Line's ability to shape perceptions and experiences of the urban environment and urban subjectivity is based upon the profound ambiguity and ambivalence of the physical, political, cultural, and social aspects of the park's design, use, and meaning. The concept of "ambi­power" ­­ a form of power based on ambiguity, ambivalence, and ambience ­­has been developed to encapsulate this idea. 

This advances analyses of the park, and urban public space more generally, by proposing that the concepts used to appraise these spaces ­­ particularly those of neoliberalization and privatization ­­ do not adequately capture how power works in contemporary cities like New York, where these processres have long been underway and have generated critical responses that have been incorporated into urban planning and politics. The concept of ambi­power thus allows us to think through the forms of power that emerge out of the dynamics and contradictions of neoliberalization, and thus to anticipate what sorts of political dynamics we are likely to see in other urban spaces. 

Moreover, the concept of ambipower has been related to the political-economic development of New York as a postindustrial city, with an economy increasingly consisting of what has been alternatively dubbed "biopolitical production" or "immaterial labor." As a number of scholars have noted, lively public spaces like the High Line can serve an important productive function, as spaces in which value can be created and potentially captured for profitable ends. The concept of ambipower has been developed to take this into account, as it appears to be facilitate the productive governance of such urban public spaces in a politically effective way. 

In addition, the concept of ambi­power seems to have relevance outside of specifically urban contexts, giving it a potentially more generalized applicablity.
